group_1.textRight: Lady Nayuta, dinner is prepared.

group_1.textLeft: Thank you!

group_1.textRight: Let us eat.

group_1.textLeft: Let us eat.
Oh my, this fish you cooked is@incredibly delicious!

group_1.textRight: It's poêlé.
I got some cabbage, cod, and potatoes@at a low price,
so I chopped the potatoes and cabbage@and sprinkled it with garlic...

group_1.textLeft: I'm not sure I understood all of that@just now.

group_1.textRight: I can hardly believe this is coming from@someone that got a 100%.

group_1.textLeft: I would rather bask in the glow of those@results for the rest of the day.

group_1.textRight: I suppose that is inevitable, but I think@you should keep it in moderation.

group_1.textLeft: I swear on my hundred that I will@celebrate in moderation.

group_1.textRight: *Sigh* What can I say...
Children and their parents can be@so different, can't they?
Your father is so calm and collected.

group_1.textLeft: Ah, that must have been a sigh of fatigue.
It's fine; I am still a junior high school girl.
There is no way I can have the same refined@and cool character as Papa.
Of course children and parents are different@from one another.

group_1.textRight: A difference in character...that's it.@That may be the most accurate expression.
But if you start measuring out character,
then I would have to say@Lady Touka is a genius.
The character that Lady Touka exudes@is in itself a different kind of character,
one that is nearly on the same level@as your father, Lady Nayuta.

group_1.textLeft: Oh, you were referring to Touka.
Hmm, I'm not so sure about@that anymore.

group_1.textRight: I was teasing you since you're@in such high spirits.

group_1.textLeft: How terrible of you!
And I don't approve of you saying that@Touka and Papa are the same.
They are nothing alike, and Touka would@hate the thought of it as well.

group_1.textRight: I retract my statement.

group_1.textLeft: Now then, I would like to know@your test results, Rabi.
I know your school was testing@at the same time.

group_1.textRight: Why do you want to know that?
Could it be that Lady Nayuta is@the detestable type...
...that only asks others about their score@when she herself scored well?

group_1.textLeft: Y-you're wrong.
I just wanted us to show each other@our scores like we were friends.

group_1.textRight: *Sigh*

group_1.textLeft: And only with this math score do I have@the confidence that I have prevailed...

group_1.textRight: So you do have a bit of a mean streak@to your character after all, then?
And I don't think there can be a concept of winning@or losing when our schools and grades are@both different,
but here, take it.

group_1.textLeft: [chara:103701:effect_emotion_surprise_0][se:7226_shock]...?!
E-every subject...all hundreds...?
S-such a thing is possible...?

group_1.textRight: ...Once in a while.

group_1.textLeft: Nngh...! That makes me feel@so insignificant...!
